G.L. c. 218 \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 21.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218 §§ 19 and 21, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts, which is within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 212 \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212 § 3 because the amount in controversy exceeds $7,000.

G.L. c. 148 \u00a7\u00a7 26E and 27A.proposition: The Defendant, as landlord and property owner, had a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, including ensuring that smoke detectors in common hallways were operational and properly maintained as required by G.L. c. 148 §§ 26E and 27A and the Massachusetts State Fire Code, 527 C.M.R. 1.00.

527 C.M.R. 1.00.proposition: The Defendant, as landlord and property owner, had a statutory and common-law duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, including ensuring that smoke detectors in common hallways were operational and properly maintained as required by G.L. c. 148 §§ 26E and 27A and the Massachusetts State Fire Code, 527 C.M.R. 1.00.

527 C.M.R. 1.00 \u00a7 13.7.2.14.1.proposition: This duty includes compliance with applicable fire safety statutes and regulations requiring operable smoke detectors in multi-unit dwellings.

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition for tenants and lawful visitors.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that, under Massachusetts law, landlords owe a duty of reasonable care regarding the safety of premises, and in particular had already held that landlords are liable in negligence for failure to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways for tenants and their guests. Young v. Garwacki extends that general negligence duty beyond common areas to include rented premises themselves, but it does so by affirming and building on the preexisting rule that landlords must reasonably maintain common areas for tenants and lawful visitors. Thus it supports the stated proposition, even though the specific facts concern a demised, not common, area.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that ‘the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.’ … In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition for tenants and lawful visitors.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the Massachusetts common-law duty of an owner or possessor of land to lawful visitors, including the obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition. Although the case ultimately concerns whether that duty extends to altering an adjacent state highway (and holds it does not), the court clearly reaffirms the underlying general principle that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care regarding their premises and common areas to tenants and lawful visitors.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: "It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988)."

Massachusetts Building Code 780 C.M.R. \.proposition: Defendant’s negligent failure constitutes a violation of Massachusetts Building Code 780 C.M.R. § 907.2.11 and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.482, which require that landlords maintain operational smoke detectors in common hallways of residential buildings.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendant’s negligent failure constitutes a violation of Massachusetts Building Code 780 C.M.R. § 907.2.11 and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.482, which require that landlords maintain operational smoke detectors in common hallways of residential buildings.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: The violation of safety statutes designed to protect tenants constitutes evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns safety statutes designed to protect tenants, but this opinion involves a liquor liability case and violation of G.L. c. 138, § 69 (a dram shop statute), not a statute protecting tenants. While the court reiterates that violation of such a safety statute is only ‘some evidence’ of negligence and not negligence per se, it does so in the context of alcohol service to a patron, not landlord-tenant safety. Thus, the case supports the general evidentiary use of statutory violations in negligence, but not specifically in the tenant context described in the proposition.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. … Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.”

St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 61.proposition: The violation of safety statutes designed to protect tenants constitutes evidence of negligence.
St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 61.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the evidentiary effect of violating safety statutes and regulations, but it does so in a general way and not specifically in the context of statutes "designed to protect tenants." The court states that violations of statutes or regulations are not negligence per se but are some evidence of negligence, and applies this to construction and building code provisions relating to a homeowner and contractor, not landlord-tenant safety statutes. Thus, while it supports the broader evidentiary principle, it does not support the narrower tenant-focused proposition.
St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 61.relevant_excerpt: “We do not construe a safety statute to establish a new civil cause of action without express terms or clear legislative intent to that effect. … Nor do violations of a statute or regulations constitute negligence per se; they are only some evidence of negligence. See MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp., 394 Mass. 131, 139-140 (1985); LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979); Perry v. Medeiros, supra at 841.”

G.L. c. 186 \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated its implied covenant to maintain habitable and safe premises pursuant to G.L. c. 186 § 14 and Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated its implied covenant to maintain habitable and safe premises pursuant to G.L. c. 186 § 14 and Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a separate opinion (Quirico, J., concurring/dissenting) discussing implied obligations based on the State Sanitary Code and related statutes, not specifically on G.L. c. 186 § 14 or an "implied covenant" under that section. Hemingway as a case is foundational for recognizing an implied warranty/habitability obligation in residential tenancies, but this excerpt does not tie that duty to c. 186 § 14 and instead frames it in terms of statutory code-compliance and implied contractual obligations. Thus, using this case as direct authority for a violation of an implied covenant "pursuant to G.L. c. 186 § 14" overstates what this opinion section establishes.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that failure to maintain functional smoke detectors in multi-unit dwellings creates a foreseeable risk of fire-related injury.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a homeowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care in securing firearms stored in her single-family home, particularly given a known violent, mentally unstable person with unsupervised access. It does not address fire safety, smoke detectors, multi‑unit dwellings, or any duty related to maintaining functional smoke detectors or the foreseeability of fire‑related injuries. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about smoke detectors in multi‑unit housing.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s inaction constitutes a breach of ordinary care under the standards articulated in Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000), and Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988), which require landlords to take reasonable steps to remedy known hazards in common areas.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: Glidden v. Maglio does not articulate or apply a standard requiring landlords to take reasonable steps to remedy known hazards in common areas. Instead, the court affirms summary judgment for the defendant because the plaintiffs failed to show causation and, additionally, produced no evidence that the defendant knew or should have known of a hazardous condition. The opinion therefore undercuts, rather than supports, a claim that the defendant’s inaction here constitutes a breach of ordinary care under a landlord‑common‑area duty theory.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care).”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constitutes a breach of ordinary care under the standards articulated in Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000), and Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988), which require landlords to take reasonable steps to remedy known hazards in common areas.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Toubiana stands for a rule that landlords must take reasonable steps to remedy known hazards in common areas, and that the defendant’s inaction constitutes a breach of ordinary care. In this case, the SJC assumed a duty of reasonable care but held, as a matter of law, that the landlord’s failure to provide a solid ceiling, warnings, a licensed operator, or a slack‑rope device did not constitute negligence because the risk was obvious and the tenant’s conduct not sufficiently foreseeable. Thus, Toubiana is authority limiting landlord liability under these facts, not affirmatively requiring remedial action on known hazards in common areas as framed in the proposition.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted.… It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence.”

Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.raw_text: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342 (1983)
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.proposition: The defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, including smoke inhalation, physical pain, emotional distress, lost wages, and property damage.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not determine that Firestone’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of any particular injuries, nor does it discuss specific categories of damages such as smoke inhalation, emotional distress, lost wages, or property damage. Instead, it addresses procedural and doctrinal issues (comparative negligence, contribution, and the interaction of negligence and warranty with workers’ compensation) and only recites the accident facts as background. The court explicitly frames proximate cause as an element the plaintiff must prove at trial rather than making any causation finding itself.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.relevant_excerpt: “It is elemental that a plaintiff may recover from a defendant in negligence only if he proves that the defendant’s breach of a duty of care owed to the plaintiff proximately caused the plaintiff’s injuries. … The problem, of course, is that any negligence of Concord Steel is not material to the issue of Firestone’s liability unless Concord Steel’s negligence, either standing alone or combined with the negligence of Correia, was the sole proximate cause of Correia’s injuries.”

Fisher v. Bell South Corp., 64 Mass. App.raw_text: Fisher v. Bell South Corp., 64 Mass. App. Ct. 286 (2005)
Fisher v. Bell South Corp., 64 Mass. App.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensatory damages permitted under Massachusetts law, including consequential and incidental damages arising from Defendant’s negligence.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all counts and issues so triable pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.
